profileText: A Representative from Maryland; born in Baltimore, Md., November 20, 1817; educated at private institutions in Baltimore; entered Lafayette College, Easton, Pa., in 1833; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1843 and commenced practice in Baltimore; elected as a candidate of the American Party to the Thirty-fourth, Thirty-fifth, and Thirty-sixth Congresses (March 4, 1855-March 3, 1861); declined to be a candidate for renomination in 1860; resumed the practice of law and also engaged in educational and religious work; trustee of Lafayette College 1865-1872; died in Baltimore, Md., on July 16, 1898; interment in Westminster Presbyterian Burying Ground.

note.content: Election unsuccessfully contested by William Pinkney Whyte.
Election unsuccessfully contested by William P. Preston.

researchRecord.name: In the Alexander H. H. Stuart papers, 1776-1878, approximately 600 items.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include Harris. A finding aid is available in the repository and online.

researchRecord.name: 1778-1928, 7 boxes.
researchRecord.description: Collection contains Harris' correspondence, speeches, essays and legal and business materials.

researchRecord.name: In the Daniel Webster Papers, 1850, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Daniel Webster to Harris written on May 13, 1850. In the letter, Webster thanks Harris for honorary membership in the Maryland Historical Society.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts
